title: Malko Tarnovo
text:
Malko Tarnovo ( , "Little Tarnovo"; as opposed to <a href="Veliko%20Tarnovo">Veliko Tarnovo</a>) is a town in <a href="Burgas%20Province">Burgas Province</a>, southeastern <a href="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, 5 km from the <a href="Turkey">Turkish</a> border. It is the only town in the interior of the Bulgarian <a href="Strandzha%20Mountains">Strandzha Mountains</a> and lies in <a href="Strandzha%20Nature%20Park">Strandzha Nature Park</a>. Malko Tarnovo is the administrative centre of the homonymous <a href="Malko%20Tarnovo%20Municipality">Malko Tarnovo Municipality</a>. As of December 2009, the town had 2,449 inhabitants.
<a href="Christianity">Christianity</a> is the dominant religion in the town, where an <a href="Eastern%20Orthodox">Eastern Orthodox</a> and an <a href="Eastern%20Rite%20Catholic">Eastern Rite Catholic</a> church exist. According to <a href="Lyubomir%20Miletich">Lyubomir Miletich</a>'s demographic survey of the Ottoman province of <a href="Edirne">Edirne</a> in "<a href="The%20Destruction%20of%20Thracian%20Bulgarians%20in%201913">The Destruction of Thracian Bulgarians in 1913</a>", published in 1918, before the wars Malko Tarnovo was a district centre inhabited by 1,200 Bulgarian <a href="Bulgarian%20Exarchate">Exarchist</a> families and 80 Eastern Catholic Bulgarian families.
Before the <a href="Balkan%20Wars">Balkan Wars</a> (1912–1913), Malko Tarnovo was a township ("<a href="qadaa">kaza</a>") of the <a href="K%C4%B1rklareli">Kırklareli</a> "<a href="sanjak">sanjak</a>" in <a href="Edirne">Edirne</a> "<a href="vilayet">vilayet</a>" as "Tırnovacık" that was ceded to Bulgaria following the wars.
Municipality.
Malko Tarnovo is the seat of Malko Tarnovo municipality, part of Burgas Province. It includes the following 14 localities:
